formattedAddress: 159 Lexington Ave, New York, NY 10016, USA
adrFormatAddress: 159 Lexington Ave, New York, NY 10016-8154, USA

editorialSummary.text: Neighborhood hot spot serving American comfort-food staples in a country-chic setting.

originalText.text: Had to make it to Penelope’s on our engagement replay weekend!  Visited for brunch 7 years ago the day after we were engaged and had and wanted to relive that experience. Start to finish it was just as wonderful. I went with the crab cake Benedict special of the day which was served in a croissant while Josh packed an omelette full of goodies - spinach, mushrooms, tomatoes, cheese and bacon. Both dishes came with a side of their breakfast potatoes and they brought a plate of biscuits with a delightful jam. Hands down hope, pray, call ahead - whatever your vibe - that the crab cake Bennie is being served the day you visit because it was da$n delicious. Our server happened to be the bartender and he was a pro managing a bar full of customers and drinks for the restaurant. Also as a side note they have two outdoor seating areas that are heated during the colder season. Everyone should give this restaurant a try - you won’t be disappointed.

originalText.text:
Hmmmmm. An interesting one to review. I love a breakfast diner in Manhattan - plenty to choose from, let's be honest. This place doesn't quite capture the 'diner' vibe, for me. Food was good (ish). I chose smoked salmon on croissant, poached eggs on top. All very delicious. Home fries, however, were not good. Lots of paprika and onions, boiled potatoes, hadn't really seen a hot griddle, or any oil, at least not today, more like a microwave on this morning, and I didn't like those at all, I'm saddened to reveal.

I won't go back here, and it's not the food. It's the service. I didn't find it friendly. I didn't feel welcome. Bottomless house blend coffee ought to mean hot fresh coffee coming round for top ups continuously. But the staff are more interested in themselves and what's on their cell phones than doing this. When I asked the server who brought my plate of food for a top up, he acknowledged a yes, went over to the bar, told the waitress, who then came over to me to ask if I wanted more coffee. She hadn't brought any with her. It felt like I had the audacity to suggest it in the first place. Not a relaxing, chilled, welcoming vibe.

Easy to fix. But I'm not sure they would get what I mean. They don't seem to understand the New York diner 'vibe'.

One more thing. If it says bottomless coffee is $4 on your blackboard, why does it say $4.50 on my check? (Plus tax of course)

originalText.text: I loved it here. It was peaceful and warm inside. Everyone was polite and welcoming. I never felt rushed to leave. I know people get breakfast and brunch so I got something else entirely and it was delicious. I loved the décor and the size…it’s a touch bohemian. I was visiting from out of town so the restaurant is in easy walking distance from many hotels in the Chelsea/Manhattan area, if you’re looking for a wonderful place to dine. I also had a lemonade and a peach Bellini. The Bellini was out of this world. Not only was it delicious, it was pretty to look at. The pricing is very reasonable considering the generous portions you receive. My experience here was lovely.

originalText.text: We stumbled upon this cafe because it was close to our hotel, but the breakfast was so delicious, we went twice during our visit to NY. The food, atmosphere and environment were all 10/10. The best part was that the price of food didn't break the bank unlike other restaurants we went to. Highly recommend!

The best part was that the price of food didn't break the bank unlike other restaurants we went to. Highly recommend!

originalText.text: A random Google search for “best places for brunch in NYC” brought up Penelope’s place. It did not disappoint! Attentive service with delectable food, server promptly! The atmosphere was warm and cozy, which gave a classic homely Christmasy feel. Highly recommend Penelope NY.
